qas.question: What technological ability with regards to detection is currently available?

answers.text: ability to detect any infectious agent

qas.question: What are the remaining blockades to the use or PCR as a standard tool of diagnosis?
What are some diseases which won't benefit from PCR methods?
PCR can't detect the presence of any bacteria when what doesn't occur?

answers.text: significant proliferation of the infectious agent

plausible_answers.text: ability to detect any infectious agent rapidly and specifically

qas.question: What supernatural ability with regards to detection is currently available?
What are the remaining blockades to the removal of PCR as a standard tool of diagnosis?
What are some diseases which help improve PCR methods?
Which blockades to use PCR are currently insurmountable?
What diseases are considered fundamentally biological healing?

context: Thus, the technological <a0_0><b4_0>ability to detect any infectious agent<a0_0/> rapidly and specifically<b4_0/> are currently available. The only remaining blockades to the use of PCR as a standard tool of diagnosis are in its <a1_0><b5_0><b7_0>cost and application<b7_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, neither of which is insurmountable. The diagnosis of a few diseases will not benefit from the development of PCR methods, such as some of the <a2_0><b6_0>clostridial diseases<b6_0/><a2_0/> (<b8_0>tetanus and botulism<b8_0/>). These diseases are fundamentally biological poisonings by relatively small numbers of infectious bacteria that produce extremely potent neurotoxins. A <a3_0>significant proliferation of the infectious agent<a3_0/> does not occur, this limits the ability of PCR to detect the presence of any bacteria.
